note.body: @nbenitez OK, I think the file to check to determine whether to skip the configure step in CMake would be `CMakeCache.txt`, because this is the file that is generated after running `cmake` (then `ninja` or `make` to build). I updated the PR to implement this change. My example test to reproduce the issue passes now.

target_title: cmake: Do not skip configure phase if CMakeCache.txt doesn't exist

note.body:
Thank you for looking into this. Here are sample files to help reproducing this issue:

**libyuv-moduleset.xml**

```xml
<?xml-stylesheet type="text/xsl" href="moduleset.xsl"?>
<moduleset>

  <metamodule id="libyuv-dependencies">
    <dependencies>
      <dep package="libyuv"/>
    </dependencies>
  </metamodule>

  <repository type="git" name="chromium.googlesource.com"
      href="https://chromium.googlesource.com"/>

  <cmake id="libyuv">
    <branch module="libyuv/libyuv"
            repo="chromium.googlesource.com"
            tag="stable"
            checkoutdir="libyuv"/>
  </cmake>
 
</moduleset>
```

**~/.config/jhbuildrc**

```bash
$ cat ~/.config/jhbuildrc 
# Specify the moduleset to be used
modulesets_dir = '~/jhbuild-modulesets'
moduleset = 'libyuv-moduleset.xml'

# Specify the modules to build
modules = ['libyuv']

# Specify where to install the built files
prefix = '~/jhbuild/install/libyuv'

# Set the number of parallel build jobs
jobs = 4

# Use local modulesets
use_local_modulesets = True
```

**run.sh**

```bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash

rm -Rf /home/dpino/.cache/jhbuild/build/libyuv
rm -Rf /home/dpino/jhbuild/checkout/*
rm -Rf /home/dpino/jhbuild/install/*
jhbuild build libyuv |& tee jhbuild.log
```

```bash
$ ./run.sh
Cloning into 'libyuv'...
Fetching origin
Already on 'stable'
Your branch is up to date with 'origin/stable'.
Current branch stable is up to date.
### last_phase:  checkout
*** Checking out libyuv *** [1/1]
git clone https://chromium.googlesource.com/libyuv/libyuv libyuv --branch stable
git remote set-url origin https://chromium.googlesource.com/libyuv/libyuv
git remote update origin
git checkout stable
git rebase origin/stable
*** Building libyuv *** [1/1]
ninja  
*** Error during phase build of libyuv: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/home/dpino/.cache/jhbuild/build/libyuv' *** [1/1]

  [1] Rerun phase build
  [2] Ignore error and continue to install
  [3] Give up on module
  [4] Start shell
  [5] Reload configuration
  [6] Go to phase "wipe directory and start over"
choice: 
```

target_title: cmake: Do not skip configure phase if CMakeCache.txt doesn't exist

note.body:
After a closer look at the code, Autogen module and Meson module doesn't have PHASE_CHECKOUT in `skip_configure()` because they check for the presence of specific files to decide if the configuration step has been run before, and if that's the case it skips configure i.e. returns TRUE from `skip_configure()`.

Autogen module checks for the `configure` file [here](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/jhbuild/-/blob/master/jhbuild/modtypes/autotools.py#L179) and Meson module for `meson-private/coredata.dat` [here](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/jhbuild/-/blob/master/jhbuild/modtypes/meson.py#L115)

I think we have to come up a similar check in CMake `skip_configure()` (as @lantw rightly sensed), because otherwise applying this MR (just adding PHASE_CHECKOUT) would cancel my fix so the bug I was trying to fix would reappear.

Tomorrow I would try to investigate what file in CMake build dir would tell us that a configuration step was completed before..

target_title: Print out error message when exiting on error

note.body: Fixes https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/jhbuild/-/issues/74

target_title: cmake: Do not skip configure phase if CMakeCache.txt doesn't exist

note.body: Other modules - [autogen](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/jhbuild/-/blob/master/jhbuild/modtypes/autotools.py#L158), [meson](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/jhbuild/-/blob/master/jhbuild/modtypes/meson.py#L102) also does not have `PHASE_CHECKOUT` in that list. Maybe you should use `PHASE_CLEAN`?

Username for 'https://gitlab.gnome.org': dpino

When pulling `yelp-xsl` module, the user is requested an username at 'https://gitlab.gnome.org'.

target_title: Allow 'patch' in Git branches

note.body:
FWIW I tried to add a test case for this but it was a pain, maybe this is helpful as a starting point for future reference:


```python
class GitBranchWithPatchesTest(JhbuildConfigTestCase):
    def setUp(self):
        super().setUp()
        module = jhbuild.modtypes.autotools.MesonModule('glib')
        self.moduleset = jhbuild.moduleset.ModuleSet(config=self.config)
        self.moduleset.add(module)
        repo = jhbuild.versioncontrol.git.GitRepository(self.config, 'GNOME', 'https://gitlab.gnome.org/')
        self.branch = jhbuild.versioncontrol.git.GitBranch(repo, 'GNOME/glib.git', 'glib')
        self.branch.config = self.config
        self.branch.patches = [
            (os.path.join(SRCDIR, 'tests', 'patches', 'glib-patch-1.patch'), 1)
        ]
        self.buildscript = mock.BuildScript(self.config, [module], self.moduleset)
        os.environ['JHBUILD_PREFIX'] = self.config.prefix

    def test_checkout(self):
        self.branch.checkout(self.buildscript)

    def tearDown(self):
        super().tearDown()
```

Add support for attribute 'version' in Git branches
Add support for attribute 'version' in Git branches

note.body:
In my case, I allow that `version` takes the value of `tag` if `version` was not set.

Many git repositories set version numbers as tags. For instance, in the case of `gstreamer`:

```bash
$ git tag | egrep ^1.20.[0-9]$
1.20.0
1.20.1
1.20.2
1.20.3
1.20.4
1.20.5
1.20.6
1.20.7
```

So, most of the times `tag` and `version` are going to match. Only in cases where `tag` is not a `version` number, a developer would like to set `version`.

target_title: Allow 'patch' in Git branches

note.body:
I think `git am` only works if the patch was generated with `git format-patch`. A patch generated with `diff` cannot be applied using `git am`, because the diff file doesn't contain commit information.

The current GitBranch code already handles the scenario where the branch can be dirty (see methods `switch_branch_if_necessary` or `rebase_current_branch`). I thought this was needed for cases in which a build fails and a developer gets into a module and applies changes there. Then, resumes the build again.

All in all, what I think it can be improved is to check whether a patch can be applied using `git am` and prioritize it over `git apply` if possible.

target_title: Allow 'patch' in Git branches

note.body:
OK, I can add an info message stating whether the patch was applied or not. However, `git apply --check` cannot distinguish between the casea a patch doesn't apply per se or a patch doesn't apply because it was already applied.

FWIW, the current `TarballBranch.do_patches` method doesn't print any error message if a patch could not be applied https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/jhbuild/-/blob/master/jhbuild/versioncontrol/tarball.py#L313

target_title: Allow 'patch' in Git branches

note.body: Agree, although I think it's better to handle this in a separated merge-request. There's another `self.check_version_git` in method `is_dirty` that should be also removed. If I do it in this merge-request is a change not related with the goal of this MR.

target_title: Allow 'patch' in Git branches

note.body:
Just thinking out loud. One problem with this is you are just leaving behind a dirty branch, that isn't very usable.

Maybe it should always create a new branch (maybe with like a hash of patches + commit) and use `git am` to make full commits on that branch.

This should be easier to detect if its been applied before, easier for a developer to inspect, switch branches, re-apply elsewhere, etc?

target_title: Allow 'patch' in Git branches

note.body:
That would work too.

It does degrade the developer use-case though because if they switch to main or something its now from a fork.

target_title: Allow 'patch' in Git branches

note.body: My point was less "switch to tarballs + patches", and more "point the module to a separate repository that carries those patches and is rebased/updated centrally".

target_title: Allow 'patch' in Git branches

note.body:
Our specific case is we build GStreamer from git and backport a few patches.

Switching to tarballs is possible... but GStreamer is a git monorepo, or like 6 separate tarballs. So switching to that sucks.

It is also useful to keep it as a git repo for developers to still have a full repo to work with.

target_title: Allow 'patch' in Git branches

note.body:
Silently ignoring if a patch applies or not isn't great.

If it was already applied it should print that and continue. If it fails to apply it should print that and error.

target_title: Allow 'patch' in Git branches

note.body: I know this is just a copy but this is from 2008. We should just raise an exception earlier if such an ancient version is used.

target_title: Allow 'patch' in Git branches

note.body:
I'm not entirely sold on the idea of applying patches on top of Git repositories; it's a necessity when using tarballs, but modules tracking Git should be modified to point to a specific branch or repository with additional patches.

Do you have any example of where this functionality would be necessary?

target_title: Add support for attribute 'version' in Git branches

note.body:
I'm a bit confused by this logic?

Shouldn't it be like:

```python
self.tag = tag
self.version = version
if version and not tag:
    raise FatalError(_('Cannot set "version" of a git branch without "tag"'))
```

note.body: Mainly because it gave the wrong perception about jhbuild to downstream packagers: you're not supposed to package this project, or use "tags". The way jhbuild works is by cloning and installing it from Git, and keeping it up to date locally.
